awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: New Image Resampling Techniques for the Mapping Nearby Galaxies at Apache Point Observatory survey in the NASA Sloan Atlas
awd_abstract_narration:
Observations of a large population of galaxies in the local universe allows us to learn about how galaxies grow through star formation. Both star formation and the interaction of gas with the central black hole can have positive and negative feedback on the rate at which stars form in galaxies. This project will develop a new analysis tool for combining data taken from many different observatories on the ground and in space. The data will be used to produce a uniform catalog of nearby galaxies with images in wavelengths from ultraviolet to infrared, as well as spectra taken from some individual galaxies. The catalog will be of value to researchers who study galaxy growth.

The Mapping Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA) survey is providing spectroscopy across the face of 10,000 nearby galaxies selected from the NASA Sloan Atlas. This data enables a broad range of science on dynamics, star formation histories, active galactic nuclei, and more. The most productive use of this new data set is to use tin conjunction with the multiwavelength imaging data sets available for these galaxies from the ultraviolet through to the infrared. The project will produce images consistently sampled in position across all of these wavelengths and within the spectra, and will publicly release the data set. They will develop a better analysis technique that minimizes the negative effects of resampling. The technique may have broad application inside and outside astronomy. An algorithm exploiting this technique will also be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The physical processes driving the formation and evolution of galaxies in an expanding, dark-matter dominated universe are still not fully understood. In particular, theories of galaxy formation cannot yet explain the striking "bimodality" in galaxy types and properties which we observe---namely, the fact that spheroidal or elliptical galaxies generally contain old, long-lived stars and little or no ongoing star formation, while spiral or disk galaxies (like our own Milky Way Galaxy) have not yet expended their cold gas supply and are still actively forming new stars. Closely linked to this bimodality in galaxy properties is the presence of
supermassive black holes in most---and possibly all---galaxies, whose initial formation and subsquent coevolution with their host galaxy are still not well-understood.


To tackle these important questions, in this project we study a well-defined sample of 10,000 nearby galaxies with existing, state-of-the-art data gathered from both ground- and space-based telescopes in the ultraviolet (UV), optical, and infrared (IR) portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. Nearby galaxies are a unique and powerful laboratory because it is possible to study not only their global, integrated properties, but also their internal structure and nuclear regions, where suppermassive black holes are found. Specifically, we use three-dimensional spectroscopy from the MaNGA (Mapping Nearby Galaxies at Apache Point Observatory) survey, and detailed imaging from NASA's GALEX and WISE ultraviolet and infrared telescopes, respectively, and from the optical DESI Legacy Imaging Surveys.

One of the foremost challenges of working with data from different surveys is that the resolution or point-spread function of each telescope and instrument is different, making it difficult to compare how much light is emitted at different wavelengths from the same part of the galaxy. This issue has severely hampered
previous efforts to infer the detailed internal and global properties of galaxies from imaging and spectroscopy spanning a wide wavelength range.

This award, which has funded a collaborative effort between Siena College and New York University, has supported the development and application of a new, state-of-the-art computational technique which accounts for the resolution differences of these various observations. Using this method and existing state-of-the-art methods, we have generated value-added catalogs and additional data and documentation which will have an immediate and long-lasting impact on the evolutionary study of galaxies and the connection between galaxy formation and the formation and feedback of supermassive black holes.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts portion of this project focused on involving Siena College undergraduate students in both the scientific and technical aspects of the project, reported on in the Siena College report for this grant.
